awd_titl_txt: Confidence Judgments and Metacognition in Comparative and Developmental Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
People regularly assess what they do and do not know.  They seek information that they lack for making good decisions, and they hesitate when they are unsure until certainty arrives through new information, or through careful reconsideration of a problem or question.  This monitoring of one's perceptions, memories, and knowledge states is critical to many intellectual and educational activities - this capacity is called metacognition. The study of the precursors to human metacognition in nonverbal animals is a strong area of focus in comparative research, and the study of the emergence of metacognition in children is a strong focus of developmental research. This project will answer new questions of metacognitive competence across species and age ranges in humans, fostering new insights into a cognitive capacity that is critical to education, decision-making, and intellectual functioning. This type of research draws great interest from the media and the public, and will be presented directly to the public through various forms such as publications, presentations, documentaries, and live demonstrations of psychological research in progress at the Smithsonian's National Zoo. Undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral associates will develop their skills as researchers, teachers, and future mentors through this research program, with a strong emphasis on the participation of underrepresented groups in this research. 

The tasks in this project will generate comparative data of cognitive monitoring by human adults, children, and nonhuman primates. The tasks will assess how these groups demonstrate confidence in what they know or do not know, adjust behavior to seek information when it is needed, and flexibly deal with varying degrees of perceptual experience, memory, and knowledge. The data will illustrate key aspects of the emergence of metacognitive control across species and across development. These non-invasive, behavioral studies will generate animal models for metacognition, expand the range of paradigms available to researchers, illuminate the early roots of metacognition in children, potentially support the study of metacognition in language-delayed or autistic children, and help ground efforts to train metacognition in populations that show impairment in this ability.

por.por_cntn:
People regularly assess what they do and do not know. When they are unsure, they can decide to seek more information to resolve that uncertainty.  This monitoring of one's perceptions, memories, and knowledge states is called metacognition. It is an essential component to nearly all intellectual and educational activities. It is an important developmental milestone for children, and one that typical emerges through the preschool and early elementary years.  It is also a capacity of great interest to those who study animal minds so as to better understand those animals, but also the evolutionary foundations of human minds.  This project assessed metacognitive competence across species and age ranges in humans toward the goal of fostering new insights into a cognitive capacity that is critical to education, decision-making, and intellectual functioning. The research was shared with the public through publications, press coverage of the research, and the real-time demonstrations of some tasks at the National Zoo in Washington, DC. The project supported the training of future scientists who worked with the investigators to develop their skills as researchers, teachers, and future mentors through this research program.

The tasks in this project generated comparative data of cognitive monitoring by human adults, children, and nonhuman primates. The tasks assessed how these groups demonstrated confidence in what they know or do not know, adjusted behavior to seek information when it is needed, and flexibly dealt with varying degrees of perceptual experience, memory, and knowledge. The data illustrated key aspects of the emergence of metacognitive control across species and across development. These non-invasive, behavioral studies generated animal models for metacognition, expanded the range of paradigms available to researchers, and illuminated the early roots of metacognition in children.

We created and used tests that often could be performed without need of verbal responses and that could be learned with little or no verbal instruction. These tasks allowed us to better understand the emergence of some forms of metacognition. The populations that were tested included two species of monkeys, two species of apes, human children, and human adults. These groups are ideal for assessing behavioral indicators of confidence and demonstrating capacities for information-seeking responses. Some of the data allowed us to distinguish how children's performance at different ages related to the performance of nonhuman primates and human adults.

We accomplished five specific goals:

(1)  We assessed metacognitive monitoring via confidence judgments in four nonhuman primate species, and compared performance in some cases to that of human children and adults. We used tasks that allowed participants to indicate their confidence about rewards they may have earned by past actions. We found that young children and other species do experience degrees of confidence that they can show through their movement behaviors. 

(2)  We examined the generality of confidence judgments by animals and young children to different situations (e.g., memory tests, perceptual tests, procedural knowledge tests) and different test formats (computerized tests and manual tests).  We also compared some of these performances to those of adult humans. In these cases, we found that metacognitive responses were efficiently used in different circumstances, although there was a clear developmental progression for pre-school aged children, and also diferences between apes' and monkeys' performances.

(3)  We assessed whether nonhuman primates and children could seek information that they needed by recognizing when they could not a correct response to make. These information-seeking behaviors and the confidence judgments described above provided new evidence of the ways in which children and some other species can engage in monitoring their own cognition and controlling their behavior to resolve uncertainty when it occurs.  

(4) We tracked the emergence of metacognitive abilities in children from 2.5 to 6 years of age. As noted, past research had indicated that this might be a crucial time window for the emergence of metacognition in humans, and our research showed that, in numerous tests, this was true.

(5) We evaluated the relation of these information-seeking behaviors and confidence judgments to other aspects of self-monitoring such as agency evaluation, or knowing what things in the environment are under one's own control versus external control. Despite our prediction that there would be a close relation among these abilities, that was not true, for children, and in some cases for adult humans.  Being aware of one's own cognitive states, and feeling uncertain or certain, may not be closely related to understanding how one can or cannot control things in the immediate environment. These results indicate the need to continue to study these relations, as well as the relation of other psychological experiences to metacognitive control and monitoring.
